stimulusHtml: Which of the following developments in the early- to mid-nineteenth century most directly enabled the emergence of the political movement that is being criticized in the source?

features.html:
“If the plan of colonizing [Africa] is intended for our benefit...we humbly and respectfully urge that it is not asked for by us....

If this plan of colonization now proposed is intended to provide a refuge and a dwelling for a portion of our brethren, who are now held in slavery in the South, we have stronger objections to it.... 

The ultimate and final abolition of slavery in the United States is, under the guidance and protection of a just God, progressing. Every year [that passes]...affords new and safe assurances that the freedom of all will...be accomplished.... 

But, if this plan of colonization shall go into effect...[the] cords, which now connect [those enslaved] with us shall be stretched...until they break; and all the sources of...affection and connection which [shared] blood bestow, will...be no more. 

To those of our brethren who shall be left behind, there will be assured perpetual slavery [and] augmented sufferings.... The southern masters will colonize only those whom [they see as dangerous].... 

[As a result of colonization parents] will be torn from their children—husbands from their wives—brothers from brothers.... The shores of America will like the sands of Africa be watered by the tears of those who will be left behind. Those who shall be carried away will roam childless, widowed, and alone, over the burning plains of Guinea....

We humbly, respectfully, and fervently entreat and beseech your disapprobation of the plan of colonization.”

Source: James Forten and Russell Perrott, African American activists, “Address to the Humane and Benevolent Inhabitants of the City and County of Philadelphia,” 1817

choicesHtml: The spread of abolition in Latin America and the continuation of slavery and racial discrimination in the United States
The expansion of European colonial control in Africa’s interior and the founding of white settler colonies in South Africa
The gradual codification of racial slavery in Indian Territory and the weakening of Black-Indigenous kinship and solidarity ties
The increased success of African Americans escaping enslavement and the establishment of maroon communities in the Upper South
